questions.text: A patient fell down from height and had a shoulder injury. He is unable to abduct the arm and unable to flex the elbow. There is loss of sensation near shoulder towards the outer aspect of arm. His limb is in position as shown in the image. What nerve roots can be involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

C5 C6 
Based on the described symptoms, the patient's injury points towards an upper trunk brachial plexus injury, often referred to as Erb's Palsy. This condition specifically affects the C5 and C6 nerve roots.

questions.text: A person had road traffic accident and suffered from multiple injuries. He had a spiral fracture of the humerus as shown in the image. What structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Radial nerve
A spiral (midshaft) fracture of the humerus commonly injures the radial nerve, which runs in the radial groove around the midshaft. Damage produces wrist drop and weakness of finger and wrist extension, with sensory loss over the dorsolateral hand and posterior forearm. Median, ulnar, and axillary nerves are less typically affected by a midshaft spiral fracture.

questions.text: In a road traffic accident, a patient presented with externally rotated leg. He was observed to have loss of dorsiflexion of the foot. Injury can be on which arrow marked area in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Loss of dorsiflexion with an externally rotated leg after trauma points to injury of the common peroneal (fibular) nerve at the fibular neck marked C. The arrow should indicate the fibular neck area where the common peroneal nerve winds superficially and is susceptible to trauma. Damage here causes foot drop (loss of dorsiflexion) and sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot, while plantarflexion (tibial nerve) may be relatively preserved.

questions.text: A patient presents with sensory loss on the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. What is the most likely level/nerve lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Common peroneal nerve
The sensory innervation of the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot is primarily supplied by the branches of the common peroneal nerve.

questions.text: Which structure is located at the level of T4?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Arch of aorta
The Arch of the Aorta is an important structure in the superior mediastinum that starts and ends at roughly the level of the T4 vertebra.

choices.text: Sweating and flushing at the preauricular region while eating
Pain due to the preauricular nerve

questions.text: What is the presentation of Frey’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sweating and flushing at the preauricular region while eating 
Frey’s syndrome (auriculotemporal syndrome) is gustatory sweating after parotid surgery. Damaged parasympathetic fibers intended for the salivary gland reinnervate sweat glands and vessels in the preauricular/temporal skin. So, when eating, the area sweats and flushes due to misdirected nerve signaling to sweat glands.

questions.text: A patient presented clinically as shown in the image. What structure is most likely to be involved in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Great saphenous vein 
Varicose veins are a common condition where the walls of your veins weaken, causing them to enlarge, bulge and twist, appearing just under the skin's surface. The great saphenous vein (GSV), the longest vein in the human body, is the most frequently affected vein in varicose vein disease.

questions.text: What is formed by the arrow marked structure shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Nucleus pulposus of Intervertebral disc 
The arrow marked structure, the notochord, forms the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc. Remnants of the notochord persist and contribute to the formation of the nucleus pulposus within the intervertebral discs. The nucleus pulposus is the gelatinous, central core of the intervertebral disc, which acts as a shock absorber and allows for spinal flexibility.

questions.text: An acutely injured worker sustains a stab wound to the central region of the palm. After 3 days, he develops swelling, severe pain, and an inability to extend the index, middle, and ring fingers. Pus accumulation is suspected in one of the palmar spaces. Which palmar space is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
The central (midpalmar) space contains the flexor tendons of digits 2–5 and can harbor pus from a stab wound in the palm. Infection here can disrupt the digital flexor tendon sheath, leading to severe pain, swelling, and impaired extension of the index, middle, and ring fingers. Infections of the other palmar spaces (thenar, hypothenar, adductor) would more typically affect the thumb or little finger movements rather than causing this specific pattern.

questions.text: A patient presents with ptosis and ophthalmoplegia. The diagnosis is orbital fissure syndrome. Which cranial nerves are most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

III, IV, V1, VI
The most likely cranial nerves involved in orbital fissure syndrome (SOFS) are: A) III, IV, V1, VI. 
Superior Orbital Fissure Syndrome involves cranial nerves III, IV, V1, and VI. Damage to III causes ptosis and ophthalmoplegia with impaired pupil constriction. IV injury leads to vertical diplopia from weakness of the superior oblique. V1 loss causes forehead/eyelid/corneal sensation loss and reduced corneal reflex. VI injury prevents lateral eye movement, producing esotropia and horizontal diplopia.

questions.text: A fish bone gets impacted in the deep piriform fossa. During surgical removal, a nerve in the floor of the fossa is accidentally injured. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Internal Laryngeal nerve
The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the piriform fossa; a fish bone impacted there or during removal can injure this nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with ptosis and a "down and out" gaze on the right side. Which cranial nerve is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cranial nerve III (oculomotor)
Ptosis and "down and out" gaze is classic sign of a third cranial nerve (oculomotor) palsy. The oculomotor nerve controls several eye muscles responsible for movement, including the levator palpebrae superioris muscle which is responsible for eyelid elevation (preventing ptosis). It also innervates several rectus muscles that control eye movement, leading to the "down and out" gaze when affected.

questions.text: Which gene mutation is characteristic of Marfan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

FBN1 (fibrillin-1)
Fibrillin-1 is a major component of the zonules of the lens, the periosteum of long bones, and the walls of large blood vessels. It also inhibits TGF-β signaling, helping to coordinate extracellular matrix assembly. When Fibrillin-1 is defective or absent, TGF-β levels rise, causing abnormal deposition of normal collagen and affecting all tissues rich in Fibrillin-1. Clinically, this can manifest as arachnodactyly (increased finger and toe length due to periosteal changes), lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) from the zonules, and vascular issues such as aortic root dilation and potential coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text: Lactic acidosis due to deficiency of which vitamin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thiamine
The three common causes of lactic acidosis due to inhibition of the Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex (PDH) are: 
(1) Exposure to inhibitors such as arsenite and mercuric ions that impair lipoic acid, a key cofactor of the PDH complex
(2) Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which deprives the complex of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), an essential coenzyme, a condition often seen in chronic alcoholics due to poor dietary intake and impaired absorption
(3) Inherited defects of the E1 component of the PDH complex (pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme), which directly reduce PDH activity.

questions.text: A breastfed infant presents with lethargy, hepatomegaly, and cataracts. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT)
In exclusively breastfed child (<6>

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma and a positive family history suggestive of Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC, also known as Lynch syndrome) most likely has a defect in which DNA repair mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mismatch Repair
HNPCC/Lynch syndrome is caused by germline mutations in mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2), leading to defective MMR and microsatellite instability.

questions.text: A man has very high triglycerides and elevated chylomicrons, with eruptive xanthomas on the skin. Which condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Familial Hyperlipidemia Type I

Eruptive xanthomas with high triglycerides and predominance of chylomicrons point to Familial Hyperlipidemia Type I (lipoprotein lipase deficiency or ApoC-II deficiency), i.e., familial chylomicronemia syndrome.

questions.text: A person’s diet is predominantly polished rice and pulses. He presents with fatigue and mild neuropathy. Which vitamin supplementation is recommended for prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vitamin B complex
A diet of polished white rice is poor in thiamine (Vitamin B1), and mild neuropathy with fatigue suggests thiamine deficiency. Prophylaxis with Vitamin B complex (which includes thiamine) is advised. Vitamin B1 deficiency is associated with:
• Beri Beri: Dry/Wet/Infantile
• Wernicke’s Encephalopathy and Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with extreme muscle weakness during exercise, along with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly. Which glycogen storage disorder is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Von Gierke’s disease 
Hypoglycemia with muscle weakness and hepatomegaly is characteristic of Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (Von Gierke’s disease). Additional features often include kidney enlargement, elevated serum uric acid, and episodes of fainting.

questions.text: Which enzyme is deficient in Fabry’s Disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

α-Galactosidase
Fabry disease is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A. This enzyme, encoded by the GLA gene, plays a crucial role in breaking down a fatty substance called globotriaosylceramide (Gb3 or GL-3) in lysosomes. Fabry’s happens to be an exception, since it shows X-Linked Recessive inheritance pattern, and absence of mental retardation or cherry red spot. The associated enzyme deficiencies for different sphingolipidoses are shown belown:

Sphingolipidoses present with the following common features;
• Autosomal recessive Inheritance
• Mental retardation
• Cherry Red Spot on retina on fundal examination
• Hepatosplenomegaly

questions.text: Which of the following can help neutralize free radicals in the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Glutathione
Key antioxidants such as vitamin E, vitamin C, glutathione, and NADPH help neutralize free radicals, functioning together with various antioxidant enzymes to eliminate reactive species from the body.
• Vit E, once oxidised, is recycled by Vit C.
• Vit C, once oxidised, is recycled by Glutathione (G-SH).
• Glutathione, once oxidised, is recycled by NADPH.

choices.text: Liver biopsy and quantitative assay of copper

questions.text: Best investigation to confirm diagnosis in a child presenting with above finding is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
.
Liver biopsy and quantitative assay of copper
Image shows formation of Kayser-Fleischer  rings, due to deposition of copper in the Descemet’s membrane. Quanitative assay of copper levels in hepatic tissue is the confirmatory test for diagnosis of Wilson’s Disease, caused due to the defect in transporter of copper, ATP7A. Increased 24 hour urinary copper, low Serum Ceruloplamsin levels and elevated Serum copper levels are presumptive tests and indicate a strong probability of suffering from Wilson’s disease.

questions.text: What does the following waveform represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

End-Tidal CO₂
The image represents a capnograph tracing showing the phases of CO₂ exhalation. The point at the end of the plateau phase (Phase III) indicates the end-tidal CO₂ (ETCO₂), which reflects the maximum concentration of CO₂ at the end of exhalation and is used as a surrogate for arterial CO₂ in monitoring ventilation.

questions.text: Which nerve is most used for neuromuscular monitoring during anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ulnar nerve
The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used site for neuromuscular monitoring, particularly at the adductor pollicis muscle. It provides reliable assessment of neuromuscular blockade due to its peripheral location and consistent response.

questions.text: A patient with maxillofacial trauma cannot be intubated or ventilated. What is the next most appropriate airway intervention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Perform a cricothyroidotomy
In a "can't intubate, can't ventilate" scenario, especially in maxillofacial trauma where upper airway access is compromised, an emergency surgical airway is needed. Cricothyroidotomy is the quickest and most effective method in such emergencies.

questions.text: An adult patient develops inspiratory stridor after extubation following prolonged ventilation. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Subglottic narrowing
Post-extubation stridor after prolonged intubation in adults is most commonly due to subglottic edema or narrowing, a complication of prolonged pressure from the endotracheal tube. This causes turbulent airflow during inspiration leading to stridor.

questions.text: A patient under anesthesia develops hyperthermia and generalized muscle rigidity. Genetic testing reveals RYR1 gene mutation. Which ion channel is implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Calcium channel
Malignant hyperthermia is caused by a mutation in the ryanodine receptor (RYR1) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which is a calcium channel. The abnormal release of calcium causes sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, and hypermetabolism.

choices.text: Suctioning of lower respiratory tract secretions

questions.text: What is the function of the marked structure on the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prevention of aspiration
The cuff on an endotracheal tube, when inflated, seals the trachea to prevent aspiration of gastric contents and allows for positive pressure ventilation. It does not aid in visualization or suctioning.

choices.text: No attendant available at home to care for the patient

questions.text: A patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. Which of the following makes the patient unsuitable for a day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

No attendant available at home to care for the patient
In rural or distant areas, arranging emergency care nearby and ensuring patient comfort during long post-surgery journeys is important; patients traveling long distances after ambulatory surgery often report high satisfaction, though hospital hotels for post-op lodging are costly and largely impractical. A universal safety feature is to discharge patients who had general anesthesia or sedation with a responsible adult escort, ideally staying 24 hours; in the U.S., patients who receive anesthesia other than unsupplemented local anesthesia are typically discharged with an escort, or otherwise not discharged.
Contraindications for day care procedures: 
1. Emergency procedures
2. ASA III patients and above, with certain exceptions
3. Poor cardiac risk such as cardiac failure, significant
arrhythmia
4. Severe aortic and mitral stenosis
5. Severe obstructive sleep apnea
6. Long duration and extensive procedures
7. Major laparoscopic surgery
8. Need for blood transfusion
9. Need for postoperative ventilation
10. Anticipated sever postoperative pain requiring
intravenous analgesics
11. Lack of hospital back up

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with high-grade fever and altered sensorium. He recently returned from a malaria-endemic region. Blood smear confirms Plasmodium falciparum infection resistant to chloroquine. The patient is diagnosed with complicated malaria. What is the most appropriate treatment of choice in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Artesunate
Explanation: Artesunate is the drug of choice for complicated or severe falciparum malaria, including cases with CNS involvement (altered sensorium). It rapidly reduces parasitemia and has better outcomes compared to quinine.

Quinine is an older treatment for severe malaria but is now second-line due to more toxicity and slower parasite clearance than artesunate. Artesunate is the current first-line for severe or cerebral falciparum malaria per WHO guidelines. Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is used for uncomplicated falciparum malaria in areas where resistance is low, but it's ineffective in severe cases. Primaquine is used to eradicate liver hypnozoites in P. vivax and P. ovale, not for P. falciparum or severe malaria.

choices.text: They decrease blood pressure by decreasing peripheral vascular resistance
They decrease blood pressure by decreasing cardiac output
They decrease blood pressure by increasing peripheral vascular resistance
They decrease blood pressure by increasing cardiac preload

questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding use of ACE inhibitors in hypertension is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

They decrease blood pressure by decreasing peripheral vascular resistance Explanation: ACE inhibitors lower blood pressure primarily by inhibiting angiotensin II formation, leading to vasodilation and decreased peripheral vascular resistance, which is their main antihypertensive mechanism.

Decreasing peripheral vascular resistance is the correct mechanism of ACE inhibitors. They do not primarily affect cardiac output (option b), nor do they increase peripheral resistance (option c). They also reduce, not increase, cardiac preload by promoting natriuresis and venodilation, making option d incorrect.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient is taking three antihypertensive drugs including diuretics but the blood pressure is not controlled. He also has hypokalemia. Which of the following drug should be used to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Spironolactone
Explanation: In a hypertensive patient with hypokalemia and poor BP control despite triple
therapy, resistant hypertension is likely. Spironolactone, an aldosterone antagonist, is the preferred fourth- line agent in such cases and also corrects hypokalemia.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that would worsen hypokalemia. Nitroglycerine is not used for chronic hypertension management; it's mainly for angina or hypertensive emergencies. Spironolactone treats resistant hypertension and corrects hypokalemia by sparing potassium. Potassium supplements correct hypokalemia but do not address resistant hypertension; they are supportive but not definitive therapy.

questions.text: Determine the total body clearance for a drug in a 70 kg male patient. The drug has an elimination half-life of 3 hours with an apparent volume of distribution of 100 ml/Kg.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1617 ml/h
Explanation: Total body clearance (Cl) is calculated using the formula:
 
Cl = (0.693 × Vd) / t½
Given:

• Vd = 100 ml/kg × 70 kg = 7000 ml
• t½ = 3 hours
So, Cl = (0.693 × 7000) / 3 ≈ 1617 ml/h

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with chronic kidney disease presents for routine follow-up. His blood pressure is 140/100 mm Hg. Urine analysis reveals significant proteinuria. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line antihypertensive agent for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Telmisartan
Explanation: In a hypertensive patient with CKD and proteinuria, ACE inhibitors or ARBs (like Telmisartan) are first-line choices as they reduce intraglomerular pressure and proteinuria, thereby slowing CKD progression.

Propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, does not offer renal protection or reduce
proteinuria. Hydrochlorothiazide is less effective in CKD, especially when eGFR is <30 ml/min/1.73 m². Telmisartan, an ARB, is nephroprotective and lowers proteinuria, making it the preferred
option. Spironolactone may be added later for resistant hypertension but carries a risk of hyperkalemia in
CKD, so it’s not first-line.

choices.text: Advise rest and no pharmacological treatment is required

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of excessive stress and difficulty maintaining a work-life balance. On examination, his blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg. His fasting blood glucose is 110 mg/dL. He has no significant past medical history and is not on any medications. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Start telmisartan
Explanation: The patient has Stage 1 hypertension (≥140/90 mm Hg) with target organ risk (stress, borderline glucose). Lifestyle modification alone is insufficient; pharmacological therapy should be initiated, and Telmisartan(an ARB) is an appropriate first-line agent.

Advise rest and no pharmacological treatment may be considered for white coat or borderline hypertension, but this patient meets criteria for drug therapy. Hydrochlorothiazide is a valid option but may worsen glucose tolerance; ARBs are preferred in prediabetics. Glucocorticoids would worsen hypertension and are contraindicated. Telmisartan is an ARB, effective and metabolically neutral, making it the best choice here.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male undergoing chemotherapy for lymphoma, who also has chronic kidney disease (CKD), presents with fatigue, pallor and exertional breathlessness. Laboratory tests show normocytic normochromic anemia with low hemoglobin and low reticulocyte count. What is the drug of choice for treating his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Darbepoetin alfa
Explanation: The patient has anemia due to CKD and chemotherapy, likely from decreased erythropoietin production. Darbepoetin alfa, an erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA), is the treatment of choice in such cases.

Darbepoetin alfa stimulates RBC production and is used for anemia in CKD and
chemotherapy. Filgrastim is a G-CSF used to treat neutropenia, not anemia. Oprelvekin stimulates platelet production (IL-11), used for thrombocytopenia. Parenteral iron is useful in iron-deficiency anemia but this case has normocytic normochromic anemia with low retic count, pointing to reduced erythropoiesis rather than iron deficiency.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with complaints of excessive thirst and frequent urination throughout the day. He mentions having to wake up multiple times at night to urinate. On further questioning, he reports a history of head injury one month ago. His fasting blood glucose is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Desmopressin
Explanation: The patient has symptoms of polyuria and polydipsia with normal blood glucose and
a history of head injury, suggesting central diabetes insipidus. Desmopressin, a synthetic ADH analog, is the treatment of choice.

Tolvaptan is a vasopressin antagonist used in SIADH, not DI. Insulin is used in diabetes mellitus, which is ruled out by normal glucose. Desmopressin replaces deficient ADH in central DI. Hydrochlorothiazide is used for nephrogenic DI but is not the first-line for central DI.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the hospital with fever and arthritis. Echocardiography confirms the presence of carditis in this patient. He gives a past history of myocardial infarction and peptic ulcer disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate anti-inflammatory agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Celecoxib 200 mg BD
Explanation: In a patient with arthritis and carditis, but with a history of MI and peptic ulcer
disease, Celecoxib (a COX-2 selective NSAID) is preferred as it offers anti-inflammatory effect with lower GI and almost similar CV profile compared to traditional NSAIDs. Among NSAIDs:

• Diclofenac and Ibuprofen both increase CV risk and have GI toxicity
• Celecoxib, although a COX-2 inhibitor, at low to moderate doses, has comparable CV risk to traditional NSAIDs (per PRECISION trial, 2016)
• It spares gastric mucosa better → hence safer in PUD

Diclofenac is a non-selective NSAID with a high cardiovascular risk, especially post-MI. Tramadol is an opioid analgesic with no anti-inflammatory properties and is unsuitable for arthritis/carditis. Celecoxib is COX-2 selective, has lower GI toxicity, and is a better option in those with both PUD and CV history when NSAID is needed. Ibuprofen increases both GI and CV risk, making it less suitable than celecoxib in this scenario.

choices.text: Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis
Inhibition of bacterial folic acid synthesis

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with complaints of leg swelling and pain in the heel, which started a few days after he began an antibiotic course for a lower respiratory tract infection. Examination reveals signs suggestive of Achilles tendinitis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Inhibition of bacterial DNA gyrase
Explanation: Fluoroquinolones (like ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin) are known to cause tendinopathy and Achilles tendon rupture, especially in older adults or those on steroids. They act by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II).

Inhibition of protein synthesis is the mechanism of drugs like aminoglycosides, macrolides, and tetracyclines. Inhibition of cell wall synthesis is how beta-lactams and glycopeptides work. DNA gyrase inhibition is the hallmark of fluoroquinolones, which are notorious for causing tendon toxicity. Inhibition of folic acid synthesis is the mechanism of sulfonamides and trimethoprim.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after accidental ingestion of tricyclic antidepressant medications. He presents with palpitations, dry mouth, mydriasis, and tachycardia. Which of the following is the most appropriate antidote in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Physostigmine
Explanation: Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose presents with anticholinergic symptoms like tachycardia, dry mouth, and mydriasis. Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, can reverse central and peripheral anticholinergic toxicity.
Lithium is a mood stabilizer and not an antidote; it can itself cause toxicity. Physostigmine reverses anticholinergic effects and is indicated in severe TCA poisoning with CNS symptoms. Naloxone is used for opioid overdose and has no effect on TCAs. Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist and is contraindicated in TCA overdose due to risk of seizures.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of allergic rhinitis has been taking cetirizine for symptom control. She presents with a complaint of excessive daytime sleepiness, which she attributes to her medication. Which of the following would be the best alternative in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fexofenadine
Explanation: Fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine that is non-sedating, making it the best alternative for a patient experiencing drowsiness with cetirizine.

Diphenhydramine, promethazine, and chlorpheniramine are all first-generation antihistamines that cross the blood-brain barrier and cause significant sedation. Fexofenadine, being a non-sedating second- generation antihistamine, is ideal for daytime use and avoids CNS side effects like sleepiness.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with a history of sudden, jerky movements of the limbs. EEG shows a chaotic high-amplitude background with multifocal spikes, consistent with hypsarrhythmia. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ACTH
Explanation: The clinical picture and EEG findings are diagnostic of infantile spasms (West syndrome). The treatment of choice is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which has the highest efficacy in stopping spasms and improving outcomes.
Ethosuximide is used for absence seizures, not effective in infantile spasms. Valproate may be used as an alternative, but ACTH is first-line. ACTH is the most effective initial therapy for infantile spasms with hypsarrhythmia. Lorazepam is used for acute seizures/status epilepticus, not for this chronic epileptic encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoing chemotherapy presents with progressive shortness of breath, dry cough, and fatigue over the past 2 weeks. He is afebrile and denies chest pain or sputum production. On examination, fine basal crepitations are heard. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral reticulonodular infiltrates, and high-resolution CT chest confirms interstitial lung. Pulmonary function tests show a restrictive pattern with FEV1 = 61% of predicted, and FEV1/FVC ratio is normal. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Bleomycin
Explanation: The patient presents with pulmonary fibrosis, evidenced by progressive dyspnea, dry cough, basal crepitations, and HRCT showing interstitial changes with restrictive PFTs. Among chemotherapeutic agents, Bleomycin is the most notorious for causing dose-dependent pulmonary fibrosis.
Cisplatin is primarily nephrotoxic and ototoxic, not typically associated with pulmonary
fibrosis. Bleomycin directly damages lung tissue, especially at high cumulative doses, causing interstitial pneumonitis and fibrosis. Doxorubicin is known for cardiotoxicity, not pulmonary effects. 5- Fluorouracil causes mucositis, myelosuppression, and cardiotoxicity, but not interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: What is the preferred pre-operative drug for the management of hypertension in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Phenoxybenzamine
Explanation: The preferred preoperative drug for pheochromocytoma is phenoxybenzamine, a long-acting, non-selective, irreversible alpha-blocker, used to control hypertension and prevent intraoperative hypertensive crises.
Telmisartan (an ARB) and amlodipine (a calcium channel blocker) are antihypertensives but do not address catecholamine-induced alpha receptor stimulation, which is central in
pheochromocytoma. Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 blocker and can be used but is short-acting and not preferred over phenoxybenzamine, which provides more stable blockade.

questions.text: What is the first line therapy for aborting the acute attack of cluster headache?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

100% oxygen
Explanation: The first-line therapy for aborting an acute cluster headache attack is inhalation of 100% oxygen at 12–15 L/min for 15–20 minutes, which provides rapid relief in most patients.
100% oxygen is the most effective and safest acute treatment. Sumatriptan is also effective and often used when oxygen is unavailable or as adjunct, but oxygen is preferred. Lithium and topiramate are used
for prophylaxis, not for aborting acute attacks.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female with a history of severe persistent asthma is currently on inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and long-acting beta-agonists (LABA). Despite adherence to therapy, she continues to have seasonal exacerbations. Her FEV₁ is within normal limits. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum IgE levels. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Subcutaneous omalizumab
In a patient with severe persistent asthma, elevated serum IgE, and poor control despite ICS + LABA, omalizumab (an anti-IgE monoclonal antibody) is the appropriate next step for targeted biologic therapy.
Oral antibiotics and SABA are useful during acute infections or mild asthma but not for persistent severe disease. Intravenous terbutaline is reserved for acute severe exacerbations, not
maintenance. Omalizumab is indicated for moderate to severe allergic asthma with high IgE
levels. Intravenous corticosteroids are used in acute exacerbations but not as a maintenance or step-up therapy in stable patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct treatment of peptic ulcer associated with H. pylori?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Omeprazole, clarithromycin and amoxicillin
Explanation: The standard first-line therapy for H. pylori-associated peptic ulcer is triple therapy with a PPI (like omeprazole), clarithromycin, and amoxicillin for 10–14 days.
Omeprazole only provides acid suppression but does not eradicate H. pylori. Metronidazole plus amoxicillin lacks the PPI and is not a complete regimen. Omeprazole, clarithromycin and amoxicillin is the correct standard triple therapy. Metronidazole, omeprazole and sucralfate is not a recommended combination and lacks a second antibiotic for effective eradication.

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer from rural India presents with 7 days of high-grade fever. On examination, a black necrotic lesion (eschar) on the lower right abdomen was seen. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Doxycycline
Explanation: The presence of eschar with high-grade fever in a rural farmer is classic for scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. Doxycycline is the drug of choice for treating scrub typhus.
Ceftriaxone is used for bacterial infections like typhoid or meningitis but is not effective against scrub typhus. Doxycycline is highly effective against rickettsial diseases including scrub typhus. Amphotericin B is an antifungal, not relevant here. Ciprofloxacin has limited efficacy in rickettsial infections and is not first-line.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents with fever, cough, and hemoptysis for the last 4 days. On examination, he is tachypneic with decreased breath sounds on the right side. A chest CT reveals a nodular lesion with a halo sign in the right upper lobe. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antifungal agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Voriconazole
Explanation: The presence of a halo sign on chest CT in a diabetic patient suggests invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, for which voriconazole is the first-line treatment according to current guidelines.
Amphotericin B is effective but reserved for resistant cases due to higher toxicity. Voriconazole is the first-
 
line antifungal for invasive aspergillosis due to superior efficacy and safety. Fluconazole is ineffective against Aspergillus species. Nystatin is only used topically or orally for mucocutaneous Candida infections and has no role in systemic fungal infections.

questions.text: A patient with Schizophrenia developed muscular dystonia and was given treatment for that. He presents with complaints of dry mouth, mydriasis, and urinary retention. Which of the following drug is likely to be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Benztropine
The patient developed extrapyramidal symptoms (dystonia) due to antipsychotics and was likely treated with benztropine, an anticholinergic. His current symptoms (dry mouth, mydriasis, urinary retention) are classic anticholinergic side effects.
Haloperidol may cause dystonia but does not cause anticholinergic symptoms. Quetiapine is less likely to cause EPS or strong anticholinergic effects. Benztropine is used to treat drug-induced dystonia but can itself cause anticholinergic toxicity. Clozapine has mild anticholinergic properties but would not be used to treat dystonia and is less likely responsible here.

questions.text: A singer is finding difficulty in raising the pitch. On examination vocal cords were depressed and bowing. Which of the nerve may be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

External Laryngeal Nerve 
The difficulty raising pitch and depressed, bowed vocal cords point to cricothyroid muscle dysfunction, which controls tension and length of the vocal cords. The cricothyroid is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus). Thus, this singer’s symptoms suggest possible involvement of the external laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A child presenting with recurrent respiratory tract infection, mouth breathing and decreased hearing.On examination hypertrophy of adenoids was documented. On tympanometry which tympanogram will be seen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Type Flat tympanogram
When a child presents with symptoms like recurrent respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, and decreased hearing, with confirmed adenoid hypertrophy, the most likely tympanogram finding would be Type Flat tympanogram (Type B tympanogram), which can also be described as a flattened tympanogram.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with a foreign body sensation. On examination, the foreign body is lodged in the pyriform sinus. Which nerve is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Internal Laryngeal Nerve
Sensation from the pyriform sinus (part of the laryngopharynx) is carried by the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus). The glossopharyngeal nerve, recurrent laryngeal nerve, and external laryngeal nerve have different sensory/motor domains.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with hearing loss, mouth breathing, and poor school performance. Which condition best explains these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Otitis Media with Effusion (OME)
Otitis media with effusion (glue ear) explains this 9-year-old’s symptoms of fluid in the middle ear causes conductive hearing loss, which can contribute to mouth breathing from nasal congestion and impaired concentration, leading to poorer school performance.
Acute otitis media (AOM) most often occurs in 6–18 month-olds. Risk factors include immunocompromise and recent viral URIs. It is mainly due to bacteria (S. pneumoniae, nontypeable H. influenzae, M. catarrhalis) and viruses (RSV, rhinovirus, adenovirus, coronavirus, influenza, parainfluenza). A viral URI causes mucosal edema and Eustachian tube obstruction, generating negative middle-ear pressure and effusion that invites bacteria. Clinically, fever, irritability, otalgia, and poor intake are common; exam shows bulging/erythematous tympanic membrane, possible perforation with otorrhea, and absent light reflex. Pneumatic otoscopy reveals poor TM mobility with a white/pale yellow tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Which subsite is most commonly associated with inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Supraglottic
Inspiratory stridor usually indicates an airway obstruction above the glottis, with the subglottic area being the narrowest part of the airway just below the vocal cords, making it the most likely site. Glottic (vocal cord) lesions often cause biphasic stridor; supraglottic obstruction (epiglottis/arytenoids) is more associated with milder or infant laryngomalacia-type presentations; tracheal (below the glottis) obstructions typically produce expiratory stridor due to higher expiratory pressures

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with facial pain and blackish discoloration in the nose. Which is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mucormycosis
Most likely diagnosis: mucormycosis (rhino-orbital). In diabetics, it presents acutely with facial pain, nasal congestion, and black necrotic nasal discharge/necrosis.

questions.text: A patient with a history of facial trauma (fall) has bleeding from the ear. What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CT scan
CT scan of the head. It quickly reveals skull fractures, intracranial hemorrhage, and other injuries after facial trauma with ear bleeding. X-ray is less sensitive for brain injury; endoscopy isn’t suitable for head trauma; MRI can be useful but is slower and not the initial choice.

questions.text: Uncinate process is superiorly attached to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Middle turbinate
Uncinate process is thin curved bony process of the ethmoid bone forming part of the osteomeatal complex.
• Superior attachment: Lamina papyracea / Ethmoid roof / Middle turbinate (commonly described as middle turbinate in MCQs).
• Inferior attachment: Inferior turbinate / maxilla
Clinical importance:
• Forms medial wall of the infundibulum
• Key landmark in FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery)
• Obstruction → Chronic sinusitis

A. Inferior turbinate: located lower; uncinate is above it.

C. Superior turbinate: may extend upward, but its main attachment is to the middle turbinate.

D. Middle meatus: uncinate forms the medial border of the middle meatus, but is not directly attached to its floor.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with maxillary sinus carcinoma underwent the procedure shown in the image. Which operation is depicted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 Total maxillectomy
For maxillary sinus carcinoma, a total (or radical) maxillectomy removes the entire maxilla to achieve wide margins, whereas partial maxillectomy preserves part of the maxilla. Ethmoidectomies are for ethmoid tumors and do not address the maxillary sinus.

questions.text: A patient in respiratory distress cannot be intubated. What is the next step in airway management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cricothyrotomy
If a patient cannot be intubated and is in respiratory distress, an emergency cricothyrotomy provides rapid, definitive access to the airway when other methods (nasopharyngeal/shallow devices or LMA) are insufficient.
Emergency airway of choice:
• Cricothyrotomy (Emergency front-of-neck access)
• Quickest and life-saving in cannot intubate, cannot ventilate situations
• Provides definitive oxygenation until formal tracheostomy if required

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient presents with sensorineural hearing loss, characterized by high-frequency deterioration and worsening of symptoms in noisy surroundings. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Presbycusis
The most likely diagnosis for a 75-year-old patient with sensorineural hearing loss, high-frequency deterioration, and worsening symptoms in noisy environments is Presbycusis. 
Features of Presbycusis:
• Bilateral, symmetrical, progressive SNHL
• High frequencies lost first
• Difficulty in speech discrimination especially in noisy environments
• Pathology: Degeneration of hair cells at the basal turn of cochlea (affecting high frequencies)

questions.text: Narrowest part of Larynx in adult:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Glottic 
The glottis is the narrow part of the larynx in adults, defined by the vocal folds and the rima glottidis, through which air flow is regulated for speech and breathing. Supraglottic refers to the region above the glottis (epiglottis and laryngeal vestibule), while subglottic denotes the area below the glottis extending to the trachea.

questions.text: What is the function the marked area as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prevention of aspiration 
The cuff around an endotracheal tube seals the trachea to prevent secretions from entering the lower airways, reducing the risk of aspiration and enhancing ventilation safety. Role of the Cuff in a Tracheostomy Tube: The cuff is an inflatable balloon located near the distal end of some tracheostomy tubes. Functions of the Cuff: 
1. Prevents Aspiration: The cuff seals the airway, reducing the risk of saliva, gastric contents, or secretions entering the lungs. 
2. Ensures Effective Positive Pressure Ventilation: In mechanically ventilated patients, the cuff prevents air from leaking around the tube, allowing full delivery of ventilatory support. 
3. Stabilizes the Tube: Helps keep the tracheostomy tube in place, especially in restless or critically ill patients. 
4. Improves Oxygenation: By preventing air leak, it ensures accurate oxygen delivery.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with hearing loss, mouth breathing, and poor school performance. Which type of hearing loss is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Conductive deafness
Conductive hearing loss is most likely. Chronic mouth breathing suggests Eustachian tube dysfunction with middle-ear effusion (glue ear), common in children and a frequent cause of conductive loss. This can impair language development and school performance. While sensorineural or mixed losses occur, the mouth-breathing clue points to a conductive component.

questions.text: A lateral view of the face shows a highlighted area 2 anterior to the ear. Which type of abscess is most likely indicated in this region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Zygomatic abscess
A zygomatic abscess is an extracranial complication of otitis media with infection spreading to the zygomatic root (anterior to the ear), causing swelling in the zygomatic area. Other abscesses differ: Catelli’s abscess is posterior to the mastoid or near the mastoid tip; Luc’s abscess is a subperiosteal collection under the temporalis muscle (above the ear); Bezold’s abscess lies deep to the sternocleidomastoid in the neck.

questions.text: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are protective against all of the following cancers except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cervical cancer 
Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are protective against endometrial, ovarian, and colorectal cancers, but not cervical cancer; therefore, the answer is Cervical cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) safe according to MEC1?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 HIV infection
According to the World Health Organization (WHO)'s Medical Eligibility Criteria for Contraceptive Use (MEC), combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) can be used without restriction by women with HIV infection, placing them in MEC Category 1.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindication to subcutaneous implant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Undiagnosed genital bleeding 
Undiagnosed genital bleeding is an absolute contraindication to inserting a subcutaneous implant. Before considering hormonal contraception, undiagnosed abnormal vaginal bleeding requires evaluation to rule out serious conditions (e.g., pregnancy or malignancy).

questions.text: In which type of disposal bag should a cotton swab with pus be discarded?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Yellow non-chlorination bag  
A cotton swab with pus is considered infectious biomedical waste and must be discarded in a yellow non-chlorination bag. This category is designated for waste contaminated with blood, body fluids, or other infectious materials that require incineration.

questions.text: A patient reports increased intake of Bajra (pearl millet) roti and now experiences drowsiness and dizziness. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ergotism
The most probable diagnosis for a patient who consumed increased amounts of Bajra (pearl millet) and now experiences drowsiness and dizziness is Ergotism. Ergotism is a poisoning caused by consuming grains, like pearl millet, that are contaminated with a fungus from the Claviceps species. This fungus produces toxic alkaloids that affect the central nervous system.

questions.text: A person has recently relocated from Nigeria to the United States. Which of the following vaccines is required for international travel from Nigeria to the USA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Yellow Fever (17D) vaccine  
This vaccine is typically required for travelers coming from countries with a risk of yellow fever transmission, including Nigeria, to the United States.
Key points about Yellow Fever vaccine:
• Requires a single dose
• Becomes valid 10 days after vaccination
• Considered necessary for entry into many countries when traveling from areas with yellow fever risk.

questions.text: A study was conducted among nursing staff to analyze the time spent on various aspects of patient care, including bed preparation, monitoring vital signs, attending doctor’s rounds, blood sampling, and drug administration. Which management technique is most appropriate for this type of analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Work Sampling
Work sampling is a statistically sound method for observing how time is spent by sampling activities at random intervals. It yields insights into how time is allocated across tasks, useful for analyzing nursing activities. It helps identify inefficiencies or workflow improvements without continuous observation.

choices.text: Fluoride level check in water source

questions.text: An elderly man with crippling deformities uses a stick, and the entire village shares the same water source. Which two investigations or interventions should be prioritised?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fluoride level check in water source 
Skeletal fluorosis results from long-term ingestion of high-fluoride drinking water. In an elderly man with crippling deformities and a shared water source, investigating water fluoride levels is essential, as excessive fluoride causes skeletal deformities, joint pain and stiffness, muscle weakness, and higher fracture risk.

questions.text: In a group, the mean blood glucose level is 105 mg/dL with standard deviation of 10 mg/dL. Assuming a normal distribution, what is the expected range of blood glucose value for approximately 95% of the population?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

85 — 125 mg/dL 
The expected range of blood glucose for approximately 95% of the population is 85 — 125 mg/dL, which corresponds to option A. In a normal distribution, about 95% of the data falls within two standard deviations of the mean. So, starting with the mean of 105 mg/dL, you subtract two standard deviations (10 mg/dL × 2 = 20 mg/dL) to get 85 mg/dL, and add two standard deviations to get 125 mg/dL.

questions.text: Vaccine, gender, pain scale is which type of data. Arrange in correct order:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nominal, nominal, ordinal 
"Vaccine" and "gender" are nominal data because their categories cannot be ranked in any meaningful order. A "pain scale," however, provides categories like "no pain," "mild pain," or "severe pain," which have a clear, ordered ranking, making it ordinal data.

questions.text: In a nuclear family of husband wife and 3 children. Time interval between the birth of last child to first child leaves home is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Complete extension 
Complete Extension: From birth of the last child to first child leaving home.

questions.text: According to the open vial policy, which of the following vaccines can be reused after opening, and which should be discarded?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Discard MR, reuse Pentavalent 
The Open Vial Policy typically dictates that vaccines like Measles and Rubella (MR) are to be discarded after a certain period (e.g., 4 hours or at the end of the immunization session, whichever is earlier) if reconstituted. 
Other vaccines like Pentavalent, DPT, Hepatitis B, and OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) can be reused in subsequent sessions for up to four weeks (28 days) if certain conditions are met, such as maintaining the cold chain.

questions.text: A long-term study found that individuals with high BP during childhood continued to have high BP in adulthood & those with low BP in childhood tended to maintain lower BP later in life.Which epidemiological concept does this pattern best illustrate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tracking 
The pattern of individuals maintaining their relative blood pressure (BP) rank from childhood into adulthood is known as tracking. This epidemiological concept describes the stability of a variable over time within a population, meaning that individuals who are high or low in a given characteristic tend to stay that way relative to their peers.

choices.text: Refer the baby for a chest X-ray and further evaluation
Perform a Mantoux test and wait for the result

questions.text: Mother brings her 9-month-old baby, concerned that a BCG scar has not appeared, although the baby received the BCG vaccine at birth. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Reassure to the mother 
A BCG scar is not a reliable indicator of vaccination status or protection. Some vaccinated infants may not develop or visible scar, and absence does not imply failure of vaccination. Routine chest X-ray or Mantoux testing is not indicated solely to assess BCG response, and a repeat BCG vaccine is not recommended without evidence of primary vaccination failure. If there are other TB exposure risks or symptoms, evaluate per local TB guidelines.

questions.text: Which among the following logos will be seen in contaminated biomedical waste management plant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option B. shows internationally recognized logo for biomedical waste management is the biohazard symbol. This distinctive sign is used to identify materials that pose a biological risk to human health or the environment.

questions.text: A study was conducted using office records over the past years to compare the incidence of disease among factory workers exposed to aniline dye and unexposed clerical staff. What type of epidemiological study is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Retrospective study 
A retrospective study examines data from the past to identify potential associations between exposure and outcome. In this scenario, the researchers are looking at past exposure to aniline dye among factory workers and comparing it to the incidence of disease in both exposed and unexposed groups, making it a retrospective study.

questions.text: A patient whose diet primarily includes pulses and rice develops bowed legs (a deformity known as "stick legs"). Which vitamin deficiency could have been prevented to avoid this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vitamin C
The condition described is Neurolathyrism, caused by excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus (khesari dal). Neurolathyrism leads to spastic paralysis of lower limbs, and people often walk with the help of a stick. Vitamin C can prevent this condition.

questions.text: A worker employed in the cement manufacturing industry is at risk of developing which of the following occupational diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Silicosis
Cement manufacturing workers are at risk mainly for silicosis because they encounter respirable crystalline silica dust from blasting, crushing, and grinding raw materials. While asbestosis relates to asbestos exposure (less typical in cement plants), byssinosis comes from vegetable dusts like cotton, and farmer’s lung from moldy hay. Thus, the occupational disease most associated with cement work is silicosis.

choices.text: Determining the balance between scaling and corrosion potential
Measuring total dissolved solids in water
Assessing only the hardness of water
Detecting the presence of biological contaminants

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the Langelier Saturation Index (LSI) in assessing water quality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Determining the balance between scaling and corrosion potential
The primary purpose of the Langelier Saturation Index (LSI) in assessing water quality is Determining the balance between scaling and corrosion potential. The LSI indicates whether water is likely to form scale deposits (due to being oversaturated with calcium carbonate) or corrode metal surfaces (due to being undersaturated).

questions.text: A child who habitually consumes wall paint is at risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lead poisoning
Children younger than 6 years are especially vulnerable to lead poisoning, which can severely affect mental and physical development. At very high levels, lead poisoning can be fatal. Lead-based paint and lead-contaminated dust in older buildings are common sources of lead poisoning in children.

questions.text: Endemic typhus is caused by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rickettsia typhi
Endemic (murine) typhus is caused by Rickettsia typhi, not R. prowazekii. The latter causes epidemic (louse-borne) typhus, while Rickettsia rickettsii causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever and Coxiella burnetii causes Q fever. So, for endemic typhus, the correct organism is R. typhi (option C).

questions.text: A factory worker sustained burns covering 25% of his body while working and later developed infections and complications related to the injury. Under the ESI Act, which of the following benefits is he entitled to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Extended Sickness Benefit
Extended Sickness Benefit (ESB) under the ESI Act provides 80% of average daily wages for insured individuals with long-term illnesses or complications (including cases of burns >20% with infection), after exhaustion of regular Sickness Benefit. The benefit starts for 124 days and can be extended up to two years. Eligibility requires continuous insurable employment for two years or more at the start of the sickness spell, along with other contributory conditions.

questions.text: A group of experts delivered individual speeches on a specific topic, with no discussions permitted between them. At the end, one person summarized the main points. What is this type of academic session called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Symposium
A symposium is a format where multiple experts present their individual perspectives on a single topic, with no interaction or debate between them, and a facilitator then summarizes the key points at the end. 
A. In a panel discussion, experts actively engage in dialogue and debate with each other, often facilitated by a moderator. 
C. While seminars often involve presentations from experts, they typically encourage discussion and interaction among participants. 
D. Workshops are designed for practical application and learning through hands-on activities, not just passive listening to expert lectures.

questions.text: During the evaluation of drinking water from a village tank, which of the following parameters exceeds the acceptable limits for safe drinking water?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cadmium — 0.03 mg/L
The World Health Organization (WHO) and Indian Standard recommend a permissible limit for cadmium in drinking water at 0.003 mg/L. The given value of 0.03 mg/L is ten times higher than the acceptable limit. Health Effects: Ingesting high levels of cadmium can lead to health effects like kidney damage.

questions.text: A man working as a mason in a Kota stone factory in Rajasthan has following chest x-ray features. Which of the following occupational exposures is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Silicosis
Kota stone is a type of limestone that contains silica. Working as a mason in a Kota stone factory involves cutting, grinding, and polishing the stone, which releases fine particles of silica dust into the air. Inhaling these dust particles over a prolonged period can lead to silicosis, a severe occupational lung disease characterized by scarring and inflammation of the lungs.

questions.text: What is the name of the technical platform created under India’s National Tele Mental Health Programme (NTMHP) to provide mental health services through a multi-level system using telephone, digital platforms, and online portals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tele-MANAS  
The technical platform created under India’s National Tele Mental Health Programme (NTMHP) is called Tele-MANAS. The service was launched in October 2022 and provides multi-level mental health support through a toll-free helpline, a mobile app, and video consultations. The program connects people with trained counselors and mental health specialists, with referrals to in-person care when needed.

choices.text: The syringe with needle should be disposed of in a black transulecent container
The used vaccine vial should be discarded in a blue bag
The used cotton swab should be discarded in a red bag
The needle should be bent and disposed of in a red bag

questions.text: During training of an Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM), you notice she has used a syringe with a needle, a vaccine vial, and a cotton swab. After completing the immunization, which of the following statements about biomedical waste disposal is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The used vaccine vial should be discarded in a blue bag  
Vaccine vials (glassware) are typically disposed of in a blue container for safe handling and recycling after disinfection. The blue bin is specifically for glass waste and metallic implants.

questions.text: Who is primarity responsible for registering eligible couple for family planning and maintaining their records under the national health system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Multipurpose Worker (Female) 
The Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM), also known as the Multipurpose Worker (Female), is primarily responsible for registering eligible couples and maintaining their family planning records under the national health system in India. While ASHAs and Anganwadi Workers assist in identifying and locating beneficiaries, the ANM maintains the official registers, such as the integrated RCH register, and submits the data for the national health programs.

questions.text: In a study, an investigator compared the mean blood pressure and standard deviation between two independent groups. Which of the following statistical tests is most appropriate to determine if the difference between the two means is statistically significant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Unpaired t-test
This test is used to compare the means of two independent groups, as stated in the problem. It assesses whether the observed difference between the two sample means is statistically significant by computing a t-statistic to determine if the difference is likely due to chance.

questions.text: Secondary prevention is most useful in the early detection treatment of which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cervical cancer 
Secondary prevention, which involves screening to detect diseases early, is most effective for cervical cancer because it has a relatively long precancerous phase, allowing for detection and treatment of precancerous lesions before they develop into invasive cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following occupational exposures is most commonly linked to the development of mesothelioma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Asbestos exposure
Asbestos exposure is recognized as the leading cause of mesothelioma. Most individuals diagnosed with mesothelioma have a documented history of asbestos exposure, often in occupational settings. The fibers are inhaled or swallowed and can lodge in the mesothelium, causing inflammation and damage that may eventually lead to cancer years or decades later.

questions.text: On January 1, 2024, an area with a population of 10,000 had 100 existing TB cases. During the year, 30 patients were cured, and 10 patients died. Additionally, new TB cases were reported during the year, and 5 of these new cases were cured before December 31, 2024. What are the incidence and prevalence of TB in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Incidence 2, Prevalence 10
The incidence of TB is 2 per 1,000 people (or 20 per 10,000 people), calculated from the 200 new cases in the year and the total population. The point prevalence at the end of the year is 10 per 1,000 people (or 100 per 10,000), calculated from the 100 existing cases, 25 new cases, and subtracting the 35 cases that were cured or died.

questions.text: Facilities provided by Ayushman Arogya Mandirs include:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Diagnostic services 
Diagnostic services are a core component of the facilities provided by Ayushman Arogya Mandirs. The mandirs (formerly known as Ayushman Bharat-Health and Wellness Centres) deliver a wide range of free and universal primary healthcare services, including essential drugs and diagnostic tests, to Indian citizens.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with cancer and undergoing chemotherapy and radiotherapy is receiving which level of prevention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tertiary
A patient diagnosed with cancer and undergoing chemotherapy and radiotherapy is receiving tertiary prevention. Tertiary prevention focuses on reducing the impact and complications of an established disease, such as controlling the spread of cancer, managing symptoms, and improving the quality of life for patients who already have the condition.

questions.text: Measles vaccine is an example of which type of vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Live attenuated vaccine
The measles vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine. A live attenuated vaccine uses a weakened form of a live virus to stimulate the immune system. The measles vaccine is derived from an attenuated strain of the measles virus, allowing it to trigger an immune response without causing the full-blown disease.

questions.text: A patient visits emergency with history of blunt trauma and following radiological image is obtained: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Blow out fracture
A blow-out fracture involves a fracture of the floor of the orbit due to blunt trauma, with the posteromedial aspect of the maxillary bone being the weakest point commonly involved. The eyeball may herniate into the maxillary sinus (enophthalmos can occur over time). Infraorbital nerve anesthesia is often present. Mechanical entrapment can occur within the fracture of the inferior rectus or inferior oblique muscle, leading to difficulty in elevation, and diplopia is typically most pronounced when looking upward.

questions.text: Which refractive error is in a patient with complains of eye strain with image depicting the focus of rays in different meidians in eye
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Astigmatism
The conoid of Sturm is a phenomenon in astigmatism, an eye condition where the cornea or lens has different refractive powers in different meridians, causing light to focus at two separate points, or lines, rather than a single point. This creates a "conoid" of light, or Sturm's conoid, with an "interval of Sturm" between the two focal lines. Unlike simple myopia (nearsightedness) or hyperopia (farsightedness), where light focuses at one point, astigmatism results in distorted or blurred vision at all distances because light rays are not focused correctly onto the retina.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the superior limbus of a patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Herbert pits
Herbert's pits are characteristic small, circular or oval depressions that form on the upper limbus (the junction of the cornea and sclera) after the healing of limbal follicles in trachoma. Healed follicle leading to depressions in upper limbus in trachoma is Herbert pits. Lymphoid infiltration with vascularization of the margin of the cornea in trachoma is known as pannus. Horner Tranta are white dots containing eosinophils, epithelial debris in Vernal keratoconjunctivitis

questions.text: In a patient with pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasma, what is the most likely visual field defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bitemporal hemianopia
Optic chiasma is compressed in pituitary adenoma. Nasal fibres of optic nerve crosses at chiasma, leading to temporal defects in both fields

questions.text: A high myopic patient presents with sudden onset of floaters and flashes in one eye, followed by a curtain like shadow in front of visual field. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
A classic case of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment begins with symptoms of a retinal tear (flashes, floaters), progresses to a visual field defect (like a curtain or shadow), and can lead to vision loss. This occurs because liquefied vitreous escapes through the tear into the subretinal space, separating the neurosensory retina from its supportive layer and causing it to detach.

questions.text: A 10 year-old presents with decreased vision. Posterior staphyloma was seen on Indirect ophthalmoscopy. What is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

High myopia
Pathological myopia is characterized by high myopia, typically exceeding 6 diopters. Its features include lattice degeneration, which is an area of retinal thinning, and lacquer cracks, which are breaks in Bruch's membrane. Choroidal neovascularization can develop from these changes. Foster–Fuchs spots represent remnants of prior bleeding. Chorioretinal atrophy contributes to a tigroid fundus appearance due to prominent choroidal vessels. Posterior staphyloma is a degenerative change associated with high axial myopia and is a major contributing factor. Peripapillary atrophy and tilted disc are also common, the latter resulting from oblique insertion of the optic nerve into the disc.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset severe eye pain, headache, blurred vision, and coloured haloes. Examination reveals a mid-dilated pupil, hazy cornea and high intraocular pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acute primary angle closure
When pupil is mid dilated such as in dim light, prone position or by cycloplegics (mydriatics), there is increased apposition surface contact between iris and lens, causing relative pupillary block with aqueous in posterior chamber pushing the iris forward and blocks the angle of the anterior chamber, leading to an attack of acute angle closure. Pupil is dilated in acute angle closure. Pupil is smal irregular in anterior uveitis

questions.text: A patient presented with painful blurred vision with photophobia after wearing contact lens. Slit-lamp exam reveals corneal stromal ring like infiltrates. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acanthamoeba
Acanthamoeba keratitis (AK) is strongly associated with contact lens wear, often linked to poor hygiene practices. Corneal stromal ring infiltrates are a characteristic, though late-stage, sign of Acanthamoeba keratitis. Pain disproportionate to clinical findings is also a distinguishing feature of AK, and photophobia and blurred vision are common symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with redness  in one eye with photophobia. On slit-lamp exam, a branched ulcer with desquamation is seen. There were reduced corneal sensation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Herpes simplex keratitis
Herpes Simplex Keratitis (HSK) typically presents with a branching or dendritic corneal ulcer, often featuring terminal bulbs as a key diagnostic clue. It frequently causes reduced corneal sensation, which can progress to neurotrophic keratitis, and is commonly accompanied by photophobia and redness.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painful eyelid swelling. With pus pointing at the base of the eyelash. What is the most likely gland involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Zeiss gland
Zeiss glands are located at the base of the eyelash and can be involved in a stye (external hordeolum). Meibomian glands reside in the tarsal plate, and their blockage or inflammation can lead to chalazion or internal hordeolum.

questions.text: The following image depicts which of the following squint
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

90 prism dioptres exotropia
Right eye is deviated outwards: Exotropia
Corneal reflex is at limbus: 45 degrees /90 prism dioptres of deviation
If reflex is at pupil: 15 degree/30 PD
If reflex is between pupil and limbus: 30 degrees/60 PD

questions.text: Which cranial nerve palsy is most likely in a child presenting with ptosis and misalignment of the eyes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

3rd nerve (oculomotor) palsy
In a child with ptosis and misalignment, 3rd nerve (oculomotor) palsy is most likely. Ptosis results from levator palpebrae superioris weakness, and “down and out” eye position occurs due to unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique when the oculomotor nerve is affected. While ptosis can occasionally appear with other palsies, its presence strongly points to CN III involvement, which also impairs most extraocular muscles except the lateral rectus (CN VI) and superior oblique (CN IV).

questions.text: A 45 year-old patient with eye examination findings showing pupil reaction to near reflex but absent on light. Where is likely lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pretectal nucleus
Neurosyphilis can affect the pretectal area and disrupt the pupillary light reflex pathway, leading to Argyll Robertson pupils that show light–near dissociation. In this condition, both direct and indirect (consensual) light reflexes are absent, while the near reflex pathway (light–near dissociation) is relatively spared.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with the following eye examination findings: a deep anterior chamber and a jet-black pupil. +11 D glasses were prescribed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aphakia
The findings of a deep anterior chamber with a jet-black pupil and the prescription of very high plus lenses (+11D) strongly point to aphakia. In aphakia, the natural lens is absent, resulting in a deep anterior chamber and a black (unpigmented) pupil appearance, and patients require high hyperopic correction with strong plus glasses or contact lenses. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Aphakia.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with complaints of delayed puberty, reduced facial hair, and gynecomastia. On examination, he has small firm testes, tall stature with long limbs, and sparse body hair. He is academically below average and has mild learning difficulties. What is the most likely chromosomal pattern in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

47, XXY 
The most likely chromosomal pattern in this patient is 47, XXY. This is characteristic of Klinefelter syndrome, a genetic condition affecting males. The combination of delayed puberty, reduced facial hair, gynecomastia, small firm testes, tall stature with long limbs, sparse body hair, and learning difficulties are classic features of Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is pro-apoptotic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bax
Bax is a pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 family member that, when activated, changes shape, inserts into the mitochondrial outer membrane, oligomerizes to form pores, and induces mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization (MOMP). This releases cytochrome c and other factors, activating caspases and apoptosis. Anti-apoptotic proteins Bcl-2, Bcl-xL, and Mcl-1 promote survival by inhibiting Bax/Bak—sequestering them or binding BH3-only proteins—to prevent MOMP.

questions.text: A young boy presents with joint swelling after a fall. Lab investigations show normal PT and raised aPTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hemophilia
The most likely diagnosis for a young boy presenting with joint swelling after a fall, along with normal PT and raised aPTT, is B. Hemophilia.

choices.text: Has a disease of chronic origin

questions.text: What is the status of the marked individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Adopted from another family
In pedigree analysis, adopted individuals are symbolized by placing their standard circle (female) or square (male) symbol within brackets. A dashed line connects this symbol to the adoptive family's line, indicating the adoption into the family. A solid line, similarly attached, would indicate adoption out of the family.

questions.text: A young patient presents with multiple dark brown to black macules on the lips and buccal mucosa. Colonoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome 
The most likely diagnosis, given the symptoms of dark brown to black macules on the lips and buccal mucosa, combined with multiple hamartomatous polyps in the colon, is A. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. 
FAP involves numerous adenomatous polyps (not hamartomatous) and can have extracolonic features like osteomas and desmoid tumors; oral pigmentation is not typical. Gardner syndrome is a variant of FAP (APC mutation) with colon polyps plus osteomas, dental abnormalities, and skin tumors. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is a nonhereditary hamartomatous polyposis with alopecia, skin and nail changes, and occurs mainly in older adults. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is characterized by hamartomatous polyps and distinctive mucocutaneous pigmented macules on the lips and buccal mucosa, which helps distinguish it from the others.

questions.text: Which CD markers are typically positive in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CD19, CD20, CD23, CD5
CLL shows CD19+, CD5+, CD23+, and dim CD20 expression; the CD5+ B-cell with CD23 positivity supports CLL and helps distinguish it from other B-cell neoplasms (e.g., MCL, which is often CD23- and cyclin D1+; CD20 is typically dim in CLL).

questions.text: A 2-year-old with fever, lymphadenopathy and H&E has hallmark cells. The diagnosis of non hodgkin lymphoma was made. Most likely translocation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

t (2:5)
The most likely translocation in a 2-year-old with fever, lymphadenopathy, hallmark cells on H&E, and a diagnosis of non-Hodgkin lymphoma is C. t(2;5).

questions.text: A young boy presents with a history of ingestion of paint chips, leaves, and soil. A blood examination is conducted. Based on the clinical history and suspected environmental exposure, what is the most likely pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lead poisoning 
The most likely pathology, given the history of a young boy ingesting paint chips, leaves, and soil, is Lead poisoning. 
The most accurate test is a venous blood lead level (above 10 µg/dL is abnormal).
